bioghist.p: William Meredith (1772-1844) was a Philadelphia attorney and president of the Schuylkill Bank. He was the third son of Jonathan Meredith, a tanner who immigrated to the United States from England in the 1750s. In 1795, William Meredith married Gertrude Gouverneur Ogden, a respected writer. The couple's eldest son was William Morris Meredith (1799-1873), who followed his father into the legal profession but made his most significant contributions as a Pennsylvania state representative (1824-1828), as the secretary of the treasury in the cabinet of Zachary Taylor (1849-1850), and as the Pennsylvania attorney general (1861-1867).

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of account books kept by William Meredith and his son, William Morris Meredith. The William Meredith volume is an account book of income and expenses, 1820-1825. Payments include personal expenses, such as tuition and pew rents, and fees paid for labor and services. Of note is a payment to "W. Strickland for draughting plan of Mr. Manigault's House" (Jan. 19, 1825). Income entries include dividends, rents, and payments on loans. The William Morris Meredith volume is an account book kept between 1867 and 1868. This brief volume lists transactions by account for items such as coal, interest, sundries, and chattels and fixtures.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
